div.p: S. Your letter was delightful to me for two reasons, honorable man. First, because you so kindly mention peace and concord, which has been the sole pursuit of my entire life. I want not myself, but you, who have been familiar to me since childhood, to be witnesses of how truly I say this, from whose number perhaps... some may be.

The second reason is that you openly share your judgment about my examination, and believe me, speaking seriously, nothing could have happened to me at this time that I would have wished for more. I greatly value that what is contained therein pleases you, and I do not refuse to render it more abundantly, in which purpose I would seem to have almost accomplished everything, if not for the request of some brothers.

For some from Savoy request that I add topics on predestination, providence, church discipline, excommunication, etc. If I follow them, the booklet, which I wished not to exceed the size of a handbook, would become too... large.

Therefore, I am stuck on what I should do. Some request that I add non-controversial topics, which, while I search for them, I hardly find any; so much has the Christian matter gone into controversy and contention. I have treated the topic of the Lord's Supper more extensively, which I also wished to publish separately if necessary; however, it will not harm if the topic, controversial today, is added in a brief order.

But what about adoration, images, and others? In summary: the intention is not to touch on everything in this brevity of the poem, so that it remains a booklet and does not become a book, etc. But I would gladly use your judgment in all other matters, whom I have always esteemed greatly and still respect due to your age and learning.
To the most honorable man, Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, the most faithful servant of Christ in the church of ZÃ¼rich and his piously esteemed lord.
